citations.narrative:
Multiple primary outdoor enclosures housing capuchins contained rusted wire paneling that were beginning to show signs
of wear and/or degradation. Additionally, an enclosure housing seven capuchins contained a metal pole along the bottom
of the enclosure that was rusted through and created a large hole in the pole. Rusted primary enclosure materials can
lose structural integrity over time and cannot be properly cleaned and sanitized. Excessive rust in surfaces where animals
have daily contact with can lead to injury and make the sanitization process difficult. Any surfaces that come in contact
with nonhuman primates must be free of excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitization, or that
affects the structural strength of the surface. Correct by August 11,2025.

The primary enclosure housing seven capuchins contained a large chicken wire patch at the bottom that was in disrepair.
Numerous sharp points were extending upward around the perimeter of the patch. These sharp points were easily
accessible to the animals and posed a risk of injury. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they
have no sharp points or edges that could injure the nonhuman primates. All primary enclosures for nonhuman primates
must be constructed and maintained in good repair. Correct by June 20, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n

narrative:
3.75(c)(1)(i) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Multiple primary outdoor enclosures housing capuchins contained rusted wire paneling that were beginning to show signs 
of wear and/or degradation. Additionally, an enclosure housing seven capuchins contained a metal pole along the bottom 
of the enclosure that was rusted through and created a large hole in the pole. Rusted primary enclosure materials can 
lose structural integrity over time and cannot be properly cleaned and sanitized. Excessive rust in surfaces where animals 
have daily contact with can lead to injury and make the sanitization process difficult. Any surfaces that come in contact 
with nonhuman primates must be free of excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitization, or that 
affects the structural strength of the surface. Correct by August 11,2025. 
3.80(a)(2)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The primary enclosure housing seven capuchins contained a large chicken wire patch at the bottom that was in disrepair. 
Numerous sharp points were extending upward around the perimeter of the patch. These sharp points were easily 
accessible to the animals and posed a risk of injury. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they 
have no sharp points or edges that could injure the nonhuman primates. All primary enclosures for nonhuman primates 
must be constructed and maintained in good repair. Correct by June 20, 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n
